title: How to Preserve Baby Food

steps.headline: Choose high-quality ingredients.
steps.description:
If you're using fruits, always pick the ripest fruit possible since it will be sweeter and more flavorful for your baby. You can use frozen produce because it's picked at the height of freshness. Try to choose organic produce, meat, dairy, and grains that haven't been grown using pesticides and avoid foods that could make your baby sick such as:
Raw, unpasteurized dairy and cheese
Honey
Food from expired or dented cans

steps.headline: Limit the seasonings you add to the food.
steps.description: While baby food doesn't have to be bland, you don't really need to add salt, sugar, or spices until the baby is a little older and eating a wide variety of foods. If you choose high-quality ingredients, they should be flavorful enough for your baby to enjoy. For a little flavor and healthy fat, drizzle olive oil over chunks of vegetables before you roast and puree them.

steps.headline: Roast, steam, or boil vegetables, meat, or eggs.
steps.description: If you're giving your baby savory foods, you'll probably need to cook them until they're soft. Consider roasting the food on a tray until it caramelizes and becomes tender. Or cut the vegetable into chunks and steam or simmer it until it's soft. Then you can mash or puree the food. For example, steam chunks of butternut squash and then mash them with a fork. Or you can roast a tray of broccoli florets and blend them until they're pureed.

steps.headline: Mash or puree the food before storing it.
steps.description: Some of the simplest baby foods for the earliest feedings are mashed up fruits or vegetables. If the food is soft, you can mash it with a spoon or fork and thin it with a little water or breast milk to make it easier for your baby to swallow. For a smoother texture, blend the food in a small food processor until there are no lumps. Remember that as you introduce food to your baby, you should only give 1 type of food at a time to ensure your baby doesn't have an allergy. For example, give your baby mashed avocado and wait a few days before giving them applesauce.

methods.name: Storing Food in the Refrigerator or Freezer

steps.headline: Refrigerate the homemade baby food for up to 1 to 2 days.
steps.description: Transfer the prepared baby food to an airtight container and put it in the refrigerator within 2 hours of making it. You can safely refrigerate fruits and vegetables for up to 2 days, but you should use foods that contain meat, fish, poultry, and eggs within 1 day. Since store-bought baby food is shelf stable, store unopened baby food at room temperature until it's expiration date. Discard any homemade or purchased food from a dish that the baby's been eating from instead of storing it again since bacteria has been introduced to the food.

steps.headline: Store the baby food in freezer safe containers.
steps.description: If you've made more food than your baby can eat within 1 to 2 days, put it in the freezer for long term storage. You can also freeze purchased purees. Spoon the baby food into an ice cube tray, small freezer containers, or a divided baby food compartment. If the ice cube tray doesn't have a lid, wrap it tightly with plastic wrap. If you bought baby food in glass jars, don't freeze them in the jars since they could crack. Transfer them to a freezer-safe container first. Label the containers with the type of food and the date. If you use freezer-safe mason jars, leave 1/2 in (1.3 cm) of headspace so the food has room to expand as it freezes.

steps.headline: Freeze the baby food for up to 1 month.
steps.description: If you used an ice cube tray to freeze the food, transfer the frozen cubes to a freezer storage bag for long term storage. If you used small containers or compartments with lids, you can leave them in the container. Freeze the food for up to 1 month. If you plan on making more baby food and will need the containers or compartments, transfer the food to freezer safe bags.

steps.headline: Reheat the refrigerated or frozen baby food.
steps.description: When you're ready to use a cube or two of baby food, remove it from the freezer and put it in the refrigerator to thaw. Then you can take the refrigerated or thawed food out of the fridge and rewarm it gently on the stove or in the microwave. Check the temperature of the food to ensure it reaches 165 °F (74 °C). Let it cool a little before you serve it to your baby. Use an instant-read thermometer to check the temperature of the food. Avoid thawing the baby food by leaving it out on the counter or putting it in standing water since these can cause bacteria to grow.

steps.headline: Be aware of the risks of canning baby food.
steps.description: Most food experts encourage people to avoid canning baby food because of the risk of botulism. If you do choose to can certain types of high-acid foods, you can process them in a water bath. Boiling the food during the canning process will destroy some of the nutrients.

steps.headline: Avoid low-acid foods such as meat, dairy, or chicken.
steps.description:
Some foods are too low in acid to preserve safely at home with a water bath. Since there's no way to guarantee that these foods are safe to preserve, avoid canning:
Pureed vegetables
Red meats such as ground beef
Poultry such as chicken or turkey
Bananas
Figs
Asian pears
Tomatoes
Melons such as cantaloupe and honeydew
Tropical fruits such as papaya, mango or coconut
Dairy and eggs

steps.headline: Select high-acid foods to process.
steps.description:
Since you won't be able to preserve a lot of produce that's low in acid, look for high-quality fruits that are highly acidic. Decide if you'd like to puree the fruits or cut them into halves or slices. Fruits that are high in acid include:
Apples: sliced or pureed
Whole berries or pitted cherries
Apricots, nectarines, or peaches: sliced or halved
Pears or plums: halved or sliced

steps.headline: Put the fruit in water or juice and bring the liquid to a boil.
steps.description: If you don't want skins on your fruit, peel them before you begin. Then remove any seeds or pits before you slice or chop the fruit and put it into a pot. Pour in enough water, apple juice, or white grape juice to cover the fruit and bring it to a boil over high heat. Then turn off the burner so you can begin to pack the fruit into the jars while it's still hot. If you're making applesauce or another puree, mash the food and cook the sauce until it's soft and as smooth as you like. For the smoothest texture, strain the puree.

steps.headline: Pack the food into sterilized jars.
steps.description: Ladle the pureed food or fruit into sterilized half-pint or pint jars and pour in the hot juice or water. Leave 1/4 in (6 mm) head space and run a skewer or knife through the food in the jars to remove any trapped air bubbles. Place a new lid on the jar and screw on a band until it's fingertip tight. It helps to use a jar lifter and funnel when filling and moving the hot jars. If you screw the bands on too tight, the air in the jar won't be able to escape as the jars are processing. This can cause the lids to buckle.

steps.headline: Process the jars in a water bath for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description:
Lower the filled jars into the rack of a water canner. Ensure that the water covers the tops of the jars by 1 in (2.5 cm) and that the jars aren't touching each other or the bottom of the canner. Bring the water to a boil and process the covered jars for:
20 minutes at altitudes between 0 and 1,000 feet (0 and 304 m). 25 minutes at altitudes between 1,001 and 6,000 feet (305 and 1828 m). 30 minutes at altitudes over 6,000 feet (1829 m).

tyn: Storing Food in the Refrigerator or Freezer
text:

You can use frozen produce because it's picked at the height of freshness. Try to choose organic produce, meat, dairy, and grains that haven't been grown using pesticides and avoid foods that could make your baby sick such as:
Raw, unpasteurized dairy and cheese
Honey
Food from expired or dented cans Limit the seasonings you add to the food. While baby food doesn't have to be bland, you don't really need to add salt, sugar, or spices until the baby is a little older and eating a wide variety of foods. If you choose high-quality ingredients, they should be flavorful enough for your baby to enjoy. For a little flavor and healthy fat, drizzle olive oil over chunks of vegetables before you roast and puree them. Roast, steam, or boil vegetables, meat, or eggs. If you're giving your baby savory foods, you'll probably need to cook them until they're soft. Consider roasting the food on a tray until it caramelizes and becomes tender. Or cut the vegetable into chunks and steam or simmer it until it's soft. Then you can mash or puree the food. For example, steam chunks of butternut squash and then mash them with a fork. Or you can roast a tray of broccoli florets and blend them until they're pureed. Mash or puree the food before storing it. Some of the simplest baby foods for the earliest feedings are mashed up fruits or vegetables. If the food is soft, you can mash it with a spoon or fork and thin it with a little water or breast milk to make it easier for your baby to swallow. For a smoother texture, blend the food in a small food processor until there are no lumps. Remember that as you introduce food to your baby, you should only give 1 type of food at a time to ensure your baby doesn't have an allergy. For example, give your baby mashed avocado and wait a few days before giving them applesauce. Storing Food in the Refrigerator or Freezer Refrigerate the homemade baby food for up to 1 to 2 days. Transfer the prepared baby food to an airtight container and put it in the refrigerator within 2 hours of making it. You can safely refrigerate fruits and vegetables for up to 2 days, but you should use foods that contain meat, fish, poultry, and eggs within 1 day. Since store-bought baby food is shelf stable, store unopened baby food at room temperature until it's expiration date. Discard any homemade or purchased food from a dish that the baby's been eating from instead of storing it again since bacteria has been introduced to the food. Store the baby food in freezer safe containers. If you've made more food than your baby can eat within 1 to 2 days, put it in the freezer for long term storage. You can also freeze purchased purees. Spoon the baby food into an ice cube tray, small freezer containers, or a divided baby food compartment. If the ice cube tray doesn't have a lid, wrap it tightly with plastic wrap. If you bought baby food in glass jars, don't freeze them in the jars since they could crack. Transfer them to a freezer-safe container first. Label the containers with the type of food and the date. If you use freezer-safe mason jars, leave 1/2 in (1.3 cm) of headspace so the food has room to expand as it freezes. Freeze the baby food for up to 1 month. If you used an ice cube tray to freeze the food, transfer the frozen cubes to a freezer storage bag for long term storage. If you used small containers or compartments with lids, you can leave them in the container. Freeze the food for up to 1 month. If you plan on making more baby food and will need the containers or compartments, transfer the food to freezer safe bags. Reheat the refrigerated or frozen baby food. When you're ready to use a cube or two of baby food, remove it from the freezer and put it in the refrigerator to thaw. Let it cool a little before you serve it to your baby. Use an instant-read thermometer to check the temperature of the food. Avoid thawing the baby food by leaving it out on the counter or putting it in standing water since these can cause bacteria to grow. Canning Select Baby Food Be aware of the risks of canning baby food. Most food experts encourage people to avoid canning baby food because of the risk of botulism. If you do choose to can certain types of high-acid foods, you can process them in a water bath. Boiling the food during the canning process will destroy some of the nutrients. Avoid low-acid foods such as meat, dairy, or chicken. Some foods are too low in acid to preserve safely at home with a water bath. Since there's no way to guarantee that these foods are safe to preserve, avoid canning:
Pureed vegetables
Red meats such as ground beef
Poultry such as chicken or turkey
Bananas
Figs
Asian pears
Tomatoes
Melons such as cantaloupe and honeydew
Tropical fruits such as papaya, mango or coconut
Dairy and eggs Select high-acid foods to process. Since you won't be able to preserve a lot of produce that's low in acid, look for high-quality fruits that are highly acidic. Decide if you'd like to puree the fruits or cut them into halves or slices. Fruits that are high in acid include:
Apples: sliced or pureed
Whole berries or pitted cherries
Apricots, nectarines, or peaches: sliced or halved
Pears or plums: halved or sliced Put the fruit in water or juice and bring the liquid to a boil. If you don't want skins on your fruit, peel them before you begin. Then remove any seeds or pits before you slice or chop the fruit and put it into a pot. Pour in enough water, apple juice, or white grape juice to cover the fruit and bring it to a boil over high heat. Then turn off the burner so you can begin to pack the fruit into the jars while it's still hot. If you're making applesauce or another puree, mash the food and cook the sauce until it's soft and as smooth as you like. For the smoothest texture, strain the puree. Pack the food into sterilized jars. Ladle the pureed food or fruit into sterilized half-pint or pint jars and pour in the hot juice or water. Leave 1/4 in (6 mm) head space and run a skewer or knife through the food in the jars to remove any trapped air bubbles. Place a new lid on the jar and screw on a band until it's fingertip tight. It helps to use a jar lifter and funnel when filling and moving the hot jars. If you screw the bands on too tight, the air in the jar won't be able to escape as the jars are processing. This can cause the lids to buckle. Process the jars in a water bath for 20 to 30 minutes. Lower the filled jars into the rack of a water canner. Ensure that the water covers the tops of the jars by 1 in (2.5 cm) and that the jars aren't touching each other or the bottom of the canner. sentences: Preparing Homemade Food Choose high-quality ingredients.
If you're using fruits, always pick the ripest fruit possible since it will be sweeter and more flavorful for your baby.
You can use frozen produce because it's picked at the height of freshness.

Try to choose organic produce, meat, dairy, and grains that haven't been grown using pesticides and avoid foods that could make your baby sick such as:
Raw, unpasteurized dairy and cheese
Honey
Food from expired or dented cans Limit the seasonings you add to the food.
While baby food doesn't have to be bland, you don't really need to add salt, sugar, or spices until the baby is a little older and eating a wide variety of foods.
If you choose high-quality ingredients, they should be flavorful enough for your baby to enjoy.
For a little flavor and healthy fat, drizzle olive oil over chunks of vegetables before you roast and puree them.
Roast, steam, or boil vegetables, meat, or eggs.
If you're giving your baby savory foods, you'll probably need to cook them until they're soft.
Consider roasting the food on a tray until it caramelizes and becomes tender.
Or cut the vegetable into chunks and steam or simmer it until it's soft.
Then you can mash or puree the food.
For example, steam chunks of butternut squash and then mash them with a fork.
Or you can roast a tray of broccoli florets and blend them until they're pureed.
Mash or puree the food before storing it.
Some of the simplest baby foods for the earliest feedings are mashed up fruits or vegetables.
If the food is soft, you can mash it with a spoon or fork and thin it with a little water or breast milk to make it easier for your baby to swallow.
For a smoother texture, blend the food in a small food processor until there are no lumps.
Remember that as you introduce food to your baby, you should only give 1 type of food at a time to ensure your baby doesn't have an allergy.
For example, give your baby mashed avocado and wait a few days before giving them applesauce.
Storing Food in the Refrigerator or Freezer Refrigerate the homemade baby food for up to 1 to 2 days.
Transfer the prepared baby food to an airtight container and put it in the refrigerator within 2 hours of making it.
You can safely refrigerate fruits and vegetables for up to 2 days, but you should use foods that contain meat, fish, poultry, and eggs within 1 day.
Since store-bought baby food is shelf stable, store unopened baby food at room temperature until it's expiration date.
Discard any homemade or purchased food from a dish that the baby's been eating from instead of storing it again since bacteria has been introduced to the food.
Store the baby food in freezer safe containers.
If you've made more food than your baby can eat within 1 to 2 days, put it in the freezer for long term storage.
You can also freeze purchased purees.
Spoon the baby food into an ice cube tray, small freezer containers, or a divided baby food compartment.
If the ice cube tray doesn't have a lid, wrap it tightly with plastic wrap.
If you bought baby food in glass jars, don't freeze them in the jars since they could crack.
Transfer them to a freezer-safe container first.
Label the containers with the type of food and the date.
If you use freezer-safe mason jars, leave 1/2 in (1.3 cm) of headspace so the food has room to expand as it freezes.
Freeze the baby food for up to 1 month.
If you used an ice cube tray to freeze the food, transfer the frozen cubes to a freezer storage bag for long term storage.
If you used small containers or compartments with lids, you can leave them in the container.
Freeze the food for up to 1 month.
If you plan on making more baby food and will need the containers or compartments, transfer the food to freezer safe bags.
Reheat the refrigerated or frozen baby food.
When you're ready to use a cube or two of baby food, remove it from the freezer and put it in the refrigerator to thaw.
Then you can take the refrigerated or thawed food out of the fridge and rewarm it gently on the stove or in the microwave.
Check the temperature of the food to ensure it reaches 165 °F (74 °C).
Let it cool a little before you serve it to your baby.
Use an instant-read thermometer to check the temperature of the food.
Avoid thawing the baby food by leaving it out on the counter or putting it in standing water since these can cause bacteria to grow.
Canning Select Baby Food Be aware of the risks of canning baby food.
Most food experts encourage people to avoid canning baby food because of the risk of botulism.
If you do choose to can certain types of high-acid foods, you can process them in a water bath.
Boiling the food during the canning process will destroy some of the nutrients.
Avoid low-acid foods such as meat, dairy, or chicken.
Some foods are too low in acid to preserve safely at home with a water bath.

Since there's no way to guarantee that these foods are safe to preserve, avoid canning:
Pureed vegetables
Red meats such as ground beef
Poultry such as chicken or turkey
Bananas
Figs
Asian pears
Tomatoes
Melons such as cantaloupe and honeydew
Tropical fruits such as papaya, mango or coconut
Dairy and eggs Select high-acid foods to process.
Since you won't be able to preserve a lot of produce that's low in acid, look for high-quality fruits that are highly acidic.
Decide if you'd like to puree the fruits or cut them into halves or slices.

Fruits that are high in acid include:
Apples: sliced or pureed
Whole berries or pitted cherries
Apricots, nectarines, or peaches: sliced or halved
Pears or plums: halved or sliced Put the fruit in water or juice and bring the liquid to a boil.
If you don't want skins on your fruit, peel them before you begin.
Then remove any seeds or pits before you slice or chop the fruit and put it into a pot.
Pour in enough water, apple juice, or white grape juice to cover the fruit and bring it to a boil over high heat.
Then turn off the burner so you can begin to pack the fruit into the jars while it's still hot.
If you're making applesauce or another puree, mash the food and cook the sauce until it's soft and as smooth as you like.
For the smoothest texture, strain the puree.
Pack the food into sterilized jars.
Ladle the pureed food or fruit into sterilized half-pint or pint jars and pour in the hot juice or water.
Leave 1/4 in (6 mm) head space and run a skewer or knife through the food in the jars to remove any trapped air bubbles.
Place a new lid on the jar and screw on a band until it's fingertip tight.
It helps to use a jar lifter and funnel when filling and moving the hot jars.
If you screw the bands on too tight, the air in the jar won't be able to escape as the jars are processing.
This can cause the lids to buckle.
Process the jars in a water bath for 20 to 30 minutes.
Lower the filled jars into the rack of a water canner.
Ensure that the water covers the tops of the jars by 1 in (2.5 cm) and that the jars aren't touching each other or the bottom of the canner.

Bring the water to a boil and process the covered jars for:
20 minutes at altitudes between 0 and 1,000 feet (0 and 304 m).
25 minutes at altitudes between 1,001 and 6,000 feet (305 and 1828 m).
30 minutes at altitudes over 6,000 feet (1829 m).
